SPH haptic interaction with multiple-fluid simulation

  • Xiaoyong Zhang1 &
  • Shiguang Liu1,2 

Virtual Reality volume 21, pages165–175(2017)Cite this article

  • 601 Accesses

  • 5 Citations

  • Metrics details

Abstract

Physics-based fluid interaction plays an important role in computer animation, with wide applications in virtual reality, computer games, digital entertainment, etc. For example, in virtual reality education and games, we often need fluid interactions like acting as an alchemist to create a potion by stirring fluid in a crucible. The traditional input devices such as a mouse and keyboard can basically input 2D information without feedback. In recent years, the continuous development of haptic device not only can achieve six degrees-of-freedom input, but also can calculate the force in virtual scenes and feedback to the user to make a better virtual experience. How to use haptic device in different kinds of virtual fluid scenarios to provide better experience is an important issue in the field of virtual reality. On the other hand, the researches on multiple-fluid interaction especially based on smoothed particle hydrodynamics (SPH) method are very lacking. Therefore, we study the key techniques of haptic interaction with SPH multiple-fluid to compensate this defect in computer graphics community. Different from the single-phase flow, interaction with multiple-fluid flow has difficulties in the realization of properties of different phases. After adding the multiple-fluid simulation, it is also important to keep haptic interaction real time. Our research is based on the mixture model. We guarantee the authenticity of multiple-fluid mixing effect while changing the drift velocity solver to improve efficiency. We employ a unified particle model to achieve rigid body–liquid coupling, and use FIR filter to smooth feedback force to the haptic device. Our novel multiple-fluid haptic simulation can provide an interactive experience for mixing liquid in virtual reality.

Introduction

In virtual reality, besides visual simulation and sound simulation, haptic rendering is another important factor for providing users with immersive experiences. Currently, haptic rendering has been successfully used in diagnosis training (Karadogan and Williams 2013), tooth-cutting simulation (Liu et al. 2008), periodontal training (Luciano et al. 2009), endoscopic surgery and training (Tavakoli et al. 2006), etc.

However, little attention has been paid for haptic interaction with fluids, especially multiple fluids. Physics-based fluid simulation has been widely used to generate realistic fluid animations. The fluid model is generally solved by the Navier–Stokes equations. The most widely used fluid modeling methods are Euler method, Lagrange method, and Lattice Boltzmann method (LBM). Among them, smoothed particle hydrodynamics (SPH) method is easy to understand, implement, and expand. It can achieve better results for meso-scale or small-scale fluid than the other two methods. Using a haptic device interactive with small-scale fluid can fully exert the advantages of SPH method and provide a better experience for users.

Limited by the input device, interacting with fluid in computer animation suffers from problems like poor realism and complicated interaction. With the development and maturity of haptic devices, fluid interaction can be extended to 3D space, and get real force feedback effects. Herein we use Geomagic touch as an interactive platform for our research. As one of the most widely used haptic devices, Geomagic touch has been widely used, with great features of high accuracy and cost efficiency. We use this 6-DoF (Degrees of Freedom) input and 3-DoF force feedback device to implement multiple-fluid haptic interaction.

In this paper, we adapt the mixture model to simulate the multiple-fluid SPH flow. We improve the solver of volume fraction and add rigid body–liquid coupling. We sample rigid body particles and perform interactions with SPH particles. A finite impulse response (FIR) filter designed in our method can obtain smoothed haptic force. The main contributions of this paper are summarized as follows:

  • Our method can provide accurate force feedback from rigid body–liquid coupling in SPH simulation. We get the haptic force by coupling rigid body particles and SPH particles, and our method can be used for different rigid body shapes and different simulation scene.

  • A scheme for coupling SPH fluid simulation and haptic device is proposed. We convert haptic device’s translational motion and rotating motion into rigid body’s motion and use FIR filters to smooth the feedback force.

  • The multiple-fluid SPH flow simulation based on mixture model is improved for achieving great haptic interaction results. We guarantee the authenticity of multiple-fluid mixing effect while changing the drift velocity solver to improve efficiency. We also expand the rigid body–liquid coupling for multiple-fluid haptic simulation.

The following sections are organized as follows. Section 2 reviews the related work. Section 3 introduces our method in detail. Section 4 demonstrates the experimental results. Finally, Sect. 5 provides the conclusion and future work.

Related works

SPH method (Müller et al. 2003) is the most popular type of Lagrangian methods, which can effectively simulate small-scale free surface fluid. In order to implement SPH fluid simulation in real time, a lot of researches use parallel computing method for acceleration. SPH fluid simulation based on GPU was firstly introduced by Amada et al. (2004). They performed nearest neighbor search (NNS) on CPU and solved Navier–Stokes equations on GPU to accelerate fluid simulation. Later, researches such as Harada et al. (2007), Zhang et al. (2008) put all the steps on GPU except for rendering scenes to further enhance the efficiency of fluid simulation.

Over the past few years, multiple-fluid simulation has received considerable attention in the graphics community. A variety of flow phenomena in our real life cannot be simulated by single-phase flow, and multiple-fluid simulation is the key to solve this phenomena. For multiple-fluid systems involving miscible fluids, the concept of volume fraction was first introduced by Müller et al. (2005) to represent the spatial distribution of different phases or components. Both the grid-based method and the SPH method have been coupled with the volume fraction representation to simulate multiple-fluid flows. Grid-based methods like Kim (2010), Misztal et al. (2014), Bao et al. (2010) assume incompressibility with the divergence-free condition and work well on topological transitions, thus achieving plausible results. Previous works based on SPH solver like Ren et al. (2014) assumed that different phases move at the same bulk velocity since the mixing phenomena is only caused by the diffusion effect due to concentration difference. So Liu et al. (2011) and Yang et al. (2015) introduced a better SPH multiple-fluid simulation which can faithfully capture complex mixing phenomena and immixing phenomena due to relative motions, turbulent interactions, and varying force distribution among multiple fluids.

In physics-based fluid animation community, it is a hot topic to study the haptic simulation for fluid in recent years. The haptic device not only can achieve six degrees-of-freedom input in 3D space, but also can calculate the force in virtual scene and feedback the force to the user to make a better virtual experience. Cirio et al. (2011, 2013) firstly introduced 6-DoF haptic interaction with SPH fluids with HAPTION Virtuose 6D35-45. Menelas et al. (2009) simulated the force from unsteady flow in fluid interaction. Yang et al. (2009) used a 3-DoF device to simulate a fluid haptic scene in real time, but the 3-DoF input device narrowed the application of this research. Sun et al. (2007) presented a touch-enabled haptic modeling framework for deformable multi-resolution surfaces. Pier et al. (2011) ran their SPH fluid interaction on GPU to improve the simulation efficiency. Different form the real-time haptic force calculation strategy method, Dobashi et al. (2007) precomputed the ad hoc algorithms to make their haptic force render in a fast way. They used Spidar-G to simulate rowing game. But this method is cumbersome to be extended to other applications.

All the previous fluid haptic simulations are generally based on grid-based method and SPH method. Yang et al. (2009) optimized and evaluated their real-time grid-based method and pointed out the importance of real time in haptic interaction. The mixing phenomena were modeled in grid-based fluid (Mora and Lee 2007, 2008). But their method is not a pure 3D method. Höver et al. (2009) introduced the use of vibrotactile feedback as a rendering modality for solid–fluid interaction. This approach enables the perception of vibrotactile feedback from virtual scenarios that resemble the experience of stepping into a water puddle or plunging a hand into a volume of fluid. Höver et al. (2009) presented extensions of the earlier work on data-driven haptic rendering. They produced results for several materials and compared the error rates of the interpolated forces with perceptual thresholds reported in the literature. Based on the SPH method, references Cirio et al. (2011, 2013) provided a realistic haptic feedback framework through physically based forces, which highlight the 6-DoF haptic feedback and the use of containers. They simulate fluids of different viscosities, but do not consider the mixing of different kinds of fluids.

Compared with the grid-based method, SPH method shows its unique advantages on haptic interaction. SPH method can simulate rigid body–liquid coupling by unified particle model and can be extended to various kinds of materials. SPH method can solve the problems in fluid haptic interaction like haptic force stability, multi-touch processing, and parallel computing. So in our research, we use SPH method for multiple-fluid haptic simulation. Here we choose Geomagic touch for our haptic research. Geomagic touch is one of the most widely used haptic devices that many haptic researches (Mora and Lee 2007, 2008; Ma et al. 2008) are based on. We use this 6-DoF input device to interact with fluid in virtual world and get 3-DoF haptic force. Our novel SPH-based multiple-fluid haptic interaction can compensate the lack of researches on multiple-fluid interaction especially based on SPH method.

Our algorithm

In this section, we will introduce the basic SPH method firstly. Then we use unified particle model to achieve rigid body–liquid coupling and extend this method for the use of haptic device. We introduce the mixture model and improve the multiple-fluid simulation for real-time haptic interaction at last.

In Fig. 1, we show the process of our simulation in each time step. We firstly solve the status of each particle on GPU; then, we send the haptic force of rigid body to the haptic device. The haptic device can send back the rigid body’s position and rotation information. The CPU gets all the particles’ position, volume fraction and isosurface for rendering.

SPH equations

SPH is the most popular Lagrangian method. It can effectively simulate small-scale free surface fluid. The motion of the incompressible Newtonian fluid is described by the Navier–Stokes equations. Navier–Stokes equations in SPH method are generally expressed as:

$$ \frac{{{\text{d}}u}}{\text{dt}} = - \frac{1}{\rho }\nabla p + \mu \nabla^{2} u + f $$
(1)
$$ \frac{{{\text{d}}\rho }}{\text{dt}} = - \rho \nabla \cdot u $$
(2)

where u denotes velocity, ρ represents density, p is pressure, f represents the external force, and μ is the viscosity coefficient. Equations (1) and (2) represent the momentum conservation and mass conservation, respectively.

In SPH, a generic field variable A at position x i is approximated using a finite set of sampling points x j located within a distance x ij  = (x i  − x j ) < h as

$$ A(x_{i} ) = \sum\limits_{j} {m_{j} \frac{{A_{j} }}{{\rho_{j} }}W(x_{ij} ,h)} $$
(3)

where h is the smoothed radius, m j denotes the mass of point j, and ρ j is the density of j.

Solving the Navier–Stokes equations needs to satisfy the momentum conservation and mass conservation. Because the quantity of SPH particles will not change after generation, it can satisfy the mass conservation in the process of its movement. SPH particle’s acceleration can be calculated by:

$$ a_{i} = \frac{{{\text{d}}u_{i} }}{\text{dt}} = \frac{{F_{i} }}{{\rho_{i} }} $$
(4)

where F i is the sum of external forces on the right side of Eq. (1). We use acceleration a i to update position of particle i.

Haptic interaction with SPH fluid

As one of the most widely used haptic devices, Geomagic touch has been widely used due to its high accuracy and cost-effective features. It has 6-DoF (Degrees of Freedom) input and 3-DoF force feedback, which can be used in research, 3D modeling, OEM application, 3D sculpture, surgery simulation, etc. We use Geomagic touch to control rigid body to interact with SPH fluid and output feedback force of rigid body. Figure 2 shows our experimental environment.

Rigid body-fluid coupling

In physics-based fluid simulation, there are two types of entities interacting with fluid, namely static entity (such as floors, walls, pool walls), and dynamic entity (such as stick, spoon, movable cup). In rigid body–liquid coupling, we need to handle these two kinds of entities, but the key is the coupling of dynamic rigid body and fluid. When the infiltration of fluid and static rigid body occurs, we assume static rigid body as static boundary and use boundary detection method to calculate resistance force from static rigid body (Moore and Wilhelms 1988).

We calculate resistance force by the equation in Baxter and Lin (2004):

$$ f^{\text{col}} = k^{s} {\text{d}}n + k^{d} (ugn)n $$
(5)

Here, d is the distance between SPH particle and static rigid body, k s denotes elastic constants, k d is damping constant, n is the normal of collision point, u is the relative velocity. We add f col into Navier–Stokes equations to achieve the coupling of dynamic rigid body and fluid.

Compared with static rigid body, rigid body dynamic faces a more complex situation. Now the most popular approach to solving this problem is unified particle model. In the unified particle model, we assume the rigid body as stable combination of rigid body particles and use Gaussian kernel function to calculate the property of rigid body particles. In our research, we use haptic device to control dynamic rigid body and interact with fluid, and feedback haptic force to user, so the accuracy of feedback force is very important.

We use the voxelization method to sample rigid body particles, and initialize property of rigid body. When the rigid body particles come into contact with the fluid particles (Fig. 3), we calculate the sum of haptic forces F haptic as the feedback force.

As shown in Fig. 3, the dynamic rigid body is sampled as particles. When the rigid body is coupling with SPH fluid, some of the rigid body particles will enter the smoothing radius of SPH particles. In our method, we calculate the interaction between SPH particles and rigid body particles to evaluate haptic force. Simultaneously, it is required to ensure there is no seepage phenomenon between rigid body and fluid particles which may break the authenticity of the simulation.

In this paper, the haptic force comes from the interaction between SPH fluid and rigid body. We solve the dynamic density and pressure of rigid body particles based on the SPH method, and then, we calculate the pressure and viscous forces of rigid body.

Different from the basic SPH method, we compute the pressure of rigid body particles using the method in Baxter and Lin (2004):

$$ P^{r} = \left\{ {\begin{array}{*{20}l} {lk^{r} (\rho - \rho ^{r} )} \hfill & {\rho ^{r} \le \rho } \hfill \\ 0 \hfill & {\rho ^{r} \le \rho } \hfill \\ \end{array} } \right. $$
(6)

Then we perform the same process for SPH particles to keep the pressure positive and prevent seepage phenomena between SPH particles and rigid particles:

$$ P^{f} = \left\{ {\begin{array}{*{20}l} {lk^{f} (\rho - \rho ^{f} )} \hfill & {\rho ^{f} \le \rho } \hfill \\ 0 \hfill & {\rho ^{f} \le \rho } \hfill \\ \end{array} } \right. $$
(7)

where ρ is the dynamic density, ρ r and ρ f are the static density of rigid body and SPH fluid, k r and k f represent the pressure coefficients.

The rigid body particles’ haptic force can be solved as follows:

$$ f_{rp}^{\text{haptic}} = f_{rp}^{\text{pres}} + f_{rp}^{\text{vis}} $$
(8)

We solve the pressure entry f pres rp and viscosity entry f vis rp as SPH particles. Readers can refer to Karadogan and Williams (2013) for details. Finally, we calculate the sum of force to update haptic force:

$$ F_{{}}^{\text{haptic}} = \sum\limits_{i} {f_{i}^{\text{haptic}} } $$
(9)

Figure 4 shows the result of our coupling method. This method is fast and shows high precision, which can satisfy the needs of haptic interaction.

Fluid interaction and haptic force rendering

The motion of the dynamic rigid body can be regarded as that it moves and rotates around its centroid without deformation. The 6-DoF input haptic device can satisfy the demand of control the rigid body in 3D space. We can employ haptic device to control rigid body in virtual scene by changing the movement and rotation of rigid body into the rigid body particles’ movement.

Assume that all the rigid particles share the same mass, and the velocity u i of particle i can be expressed as:

$$ u_{i} = u_{r} + \omega_{r} \times q_{i} $$
(10)

where u r is the velocity of rigid body’s centroid, ω r represents the angular velocity of rigid body, u i is the velocity of rigid body particle i, q i denotes the relative position between particle i and the centroid. In each time step, we input the particle position and the rotation angle by haptic device and update rigid body particles’ position so as to represent the motion of rigid body.

Another key issue for haptic interaction is the haptic force rendering. Due to the acuity of human sense of touch, haptic devices are always designed to be equipped with 1000 Hz force output. However, for interactive fluid simulation, it can achieve great visual effects by reaching more than 30 frames per second. The mismatch between the haptic frequency and visual frequency lies in our method.

It is required to evaluate the feedback force from the dynamic rigid body in each simulation step; therefore, the efficiency of the SPH fluid simulation becomes the bottleneck. In previous work, the strategy of offline computing was used in Dobashi et al. (2007), and the virtual coupling method and dual GPUs were employed in Cirio et al. (2011) to divide scene rendering and simulation into two parallel processes to enhance the computational efficiency. However, these methods either are limited by devices or suffer from poor scalability.

For the haptic interaction between rigid bodies, it is not desirable by using a filter to smooth the haptic force, because it may lead to an unnecessary softening of the surfaces by removing the high-frequency components of the resulting force. However, it was found in Baxter and Lin (2004) that for simulating the feeling of a type of fluid, the high-frequency components contain much less energy. We smooth the haptic force by filtering, which can greatly eliminate the vibration of haptic force caused by low frequency.

Therefore, we separate the haptic force update from simulation step and smooth the haptic force with a filter. We employ FIR filter with Hamming window to convert low-frequency haptic force into 1000 Hz output force which can prevent the user from feeling the vibration during operation. Here, we select a modified Bartlett–Hanning window (Baxter and Lin M 2004), which can be expressed as follows:

$$ w(n) = 0.62 - 0.48|(\frac{n}{N} - 0.5)| + 0.38\cos (2\pi (\frac{n}{N} - 0.5)) $$
(11)

where \( 0 \le n \le N \). And the window length is \( L{ = }N{ + }1 \). Although the filtering introduces some delay into the force response time, because the delay time is very short, it can be hardly noticed.

SPH multi-fluid haptic simulation

In our daily life, adding honey in water and dropping oil in soup are common multi-fluid phenomena. It depends on the properties of fluids whether they are mixing or not. Some of them are polar solvent and others are non-polar solvent. Ionic compounds and dissociable covalent compounds are dissolved by polar solvent, while non-polar solvents are capable of dissolving non-polar covalent compounds. Fluid can be divided into polar solvent and non-polar solvent. So the polar solvents can mix together and non-polar solvents are mixable, but the polar solvent cannot be mixed with non-polar solvent. Recently, multiple-fluid simulation has received much attention in the graphics community, but it was not fully studied in fluid haptic interaction. In this section, we will discuss the SPH multi-fluid simulation method and its implementation in our haptic interaction framework.

Multi-fluid mixture model

In this subsection, we will introduce the mixture model, the most widely used mathematical model in engineering for grid-based multiple-fluid flows, which can also be used in SPH fluid (Ren et al. 2014). Our method is based on this model.

In the theory of mixture model, different phases or components k of fluid can be represented by volume fraction α k and velocity u k . The multi-fluid equations of mass conservation and momentum conservation can be represented as:

$$ \frac{\partial }{\partial t}(\alpha_{k} \rho_{k} ) + \nabla \cdot (\alpha_{k} \rho_{k} u_{k} ) = 0 $$
(12)
$$ \frac{\partial }{\partial t}(\alpha_{k} \rho_{k} u_{k} ) + \nabla \cdot (\alpha_{k} \rho_{k} u_{k} u_{k} ) = \alpha_{k} \rho_{k} g - \alpha_{k} \nabla p_{k} + \nabla \cdot (\alpha_{k} T_{k} ) + F_{k} $$
(13)

The rest density of phase k is ρ k , p k is the pressure, g is gravity, T k is the viscous stress tensor, and F k is the interfacial momentum source. The volume fraction α k falls in the range between 0 and 1, and α k must meet the following conditions:

$$ \sum\limits_{k} {\alpha_{k} = 1, \, 0 \le \alpha_{k} } $$
(14)

After summing each phase of fluid, the mass conservation equations and momentum conservation equations can be rewritten as:

$$ \frac{\partial }{\partial t}(\rho_{m} ) + \nabla \cdot (\rho_{m} u_{m} ) = 0 $$
(15)
$$ \frac{\partial }{\partial t}(\rho_{m} u_{m} ) + \nabla \cdot (\rho_{m} u_{m} u_{m} ) = \rho_{m} g - \nabla p_{m} + \nabla \cdot T_{m} + \nabla \cdot T_{Dm} $$
(16)

where \( \rho_{m} \) is the mixed density, u m is the mixed velocity, p m is the mixed pressure, and T m is the mixture’s viscous stress tensor. T Dm  = −∑  k α k ρ k u mk u mk represents the convective momentum transfer between different phases, which is derived from the left-hand side of the momentum equation. u mk  = u k  − u m denotes the drift velocity.

The mass conservation equation can be rewritten as:

$$ \frac{{\partial \alpha_{k} }}{\partial t} + (u_{m} \cdot \nabla )\alpha_{k} = - \alpha_{k} \nabla \cdot u_{m} - \nabla \cdot (\alpha_{k} u_{mk} ) $$
(17)

Then the momentum conservation Eq. (18) can be reorganized as:

$$ \frac{\partial }{\partial t}u_{m} + (u_{m} \cdot \nabla )u_{m} = - \frac{{\nabla p_{m} }}{{\rho_{m} }} + g + \frac{{\nabla \cdot T_{m} }}{{\rho_{m} }} + \frac{{\nabla \cdot T_{Dm} }}{{\rho_{m} }} $$
(18)

Equations (17) and (18) represent the mixture model. The distribution of each phase can be expressed as the volume fraction of the whole fluid.

SPH multi-fluid interaction

If the phases of fluid cannot be mixed, i.e., they are polar solvent and non-polar solvent, we do not need to simulate diffusion phenomenon. The volume fraction of each SPH particle will not change under this situation. There are no additional calculations in fluid simulation to handle the mixture problems. Figure 5 shows the simulation of a three-phase immiscible fluid in a container after stirring. It can be observed from this figure that after mixing each phase still maintain their original volume fraction.

However, for the miscible flow which includes polar fluid or non-polar fluid, the non-uniform distribution of velocity fields will lead to changes of the volume fraction for each phase.

Different from single-phase fluid, we cannot assume that ∇ · u m  = 0, since in multi-fluid flow the volume fraction \( \alpha_{\text{k}} \) of each phase changes frequently and velocity of each phase u k is also different; in this paper, we solve the multi-fluid model by calculating volume fraction \( \alpha_{\text{k}} \) and mixed velocity u m in each time step as follows:

$$ \frac{{\partial \alpha_{k} }}{\partial t} = \alpha_{k} \nabla \cdot u_{m} - \nabla \cdot (\alpha_{k} u_{mk} ) - (u_{m} \cdot \nabla )\alpha_{k} $$
(19)
$$ \frac{{\partial u_{m} }}{\partial t} = - \frac{{\nabla p_{m} }}{{\rho_{m} }} + g + \frac{{\nabla \cdot T_{m} }}{{\rho_{m} }} + \frac{{\nabla \cdot T_{Dm} }}{{\rho_{m} }} + \frac{{f^{{\text{haptic}}} }}{{\rho_{m} }} - (u_{m} \cdot \nabla )u_{m} $$
(20)

Equations (19) and (20) represent the mass conservation and momentum conservation. Different from the original method, we add haptic force f haptic which would be computed when rigid body and liquid are coupling. Then we solve each term of the equations for our simulation.

The key to solve volume fraction α k is the drift velocity u mk . There are three terms in the original drift velocity solver. The first term accounts for the inertia effect, modeling the velocity differences caused by body forces. The second term denotes the pressure effect, which can promote the mixing between different phases. The third term accounts for the diffusion effect, which leads a phase to move from regions with higher concentration to those with lower concentration. In this paper, considering that the other two effects are less obvious compared with the diffusion effect, we only solve the third term for higher efficiency in the calculation of the drift velocity diffusion. Here, u mk should satisfy the following two equations:

$$ \sum\limits_{k} {\alpha_{k} u_{mk} = 0} $$
(21)
$$ u_{mk} = - \sigma_{{\text{dif}}} \left(\frac{{\nabla \alpha_{k} }}{{\alpha_{k} }} - \sum\limits_{k'} {\frac{{\nabla \alpha_{k'} \rho_{k'} }}{{\rho_{m} }}} \right) $$
(22)

Equation (21) represents the relationships of the multiple-fluid variables. Its detail calculation process can be found in Ren et al. (2014). This equation serves as the drift velocity solver in our method, where σ dif is the diffusion coefficient. We calculate ∇α k of each SPH particle i by:

$$ (\nabla \alpha_{k} )_{i} = \sum\limits_{j} {\frac{{m_{j} }}{{\rho_{j} }}} (\alpha_{kj} - \alpha_{ki} ) \cdot \nabla W(x_{ji} ,h) $$
(23)

This equation is similar to the scalar field gradient solver in SPH method. Ren et al. (2014) introduced the drift velocity solver which can ensure stability during simulation:

$$ (\alpha_{k} \nabla \cdot u_{m} )_{i} = \sum\limits_{j} {\frac{{m_{j} }}{{\rho_{j} }}} \frac{{\alpha_{kj} + \alpha_{ki} }}{2}(u_{mj} - u_{mi} ) \cdot \nabla W(x_{ji} ,h) $$
(24)
$$ (\nabla \cdot (\alpha_{k} u_{mk} ))_{i} = \sum\limits_{j} {\frac{{m_{j} }}{{\rho_{j} }}} (\alpha_{kj} u_{mkj} + \alpha_{ki} u_{mki} ) \cdot \nabla W(x_{ji} ,h) $$
(25)

where ρ j is the dynamic density of particle j. Equation (24) expresses the change of volume fraction due to the aggregate motion of the mixture, i.e., relative motion of the mixture particles. Equation (25) indicates the change of volume fraction due to the discrepancy between phase velocities, i.e., the difference of α k u mk between particles.

We calculate ∇p m by the method in the single-phase simulation as follows:

$$ \nabla p_{m} = \sum\limits_{j} {\frac{{m_{j} }}{{\rho_{j} }}} \frac{{(p_{mi} + p_{mj} )}}{2}\nabla W(x_{ji} ,h) $$
(26)

The momentum change of each phase caused by the drift velocity is ∇ · T Dm , and we solve it by:

$$ \nabla \cdot T_{Dm} = - \sum\limits_{j} {\frac{{m_{j} }}{{\rho_{j} }}} \sum\limits_{k} {\left[ {\rho_{k} \frac{{\alpha_{kj} u_{mkj} u_{mkj} + \alpha_{ki} u_{mki} u_{mki} }}{2}\nabla W(x_{ji} ,h)} \right]} $$
(27)

Because the viscosity of SPH particle is changed by the volume fraction of each phase, we solve it using

$$ \nabla \cdot T_{m} = \sum\limits_{j} {\frac{{m_{j} }}{{\rho_{j} }}} \frac{{(\mu_{i} + \mu_{j} )}}{2}(u_{mj} - u_{mi} ) \cdot \nabla^{2} W(x_{ji} ,h) $$
(28)

where the mixed viscosity coefficient μ i  = ∑  k α ki μ k and (μ i  + μ j )/(μ i  + μ j )2.2 ensure the symmetry of the viscous force.

The haptic force f haptic can be divided into f pres and f vis. When the rigid body–liquid coupling occurs, we calculate the haptic force from rigid body as follows:

$$ f_{i}^{\text{pres}} = \sum\limits_{j} {\frac{{m_{j} }}{{\rho_{j} }}} \frac{{(p_{mi} + p_{j} )}}{2}\nabla W(x_{ji} ,h) $$
(29)
$$ f_{i}^{\text{vis}} = \sum\limits_{j} {\frac{{m_{j} }}{{\rho_{j} }}} \frac{{(\mu_{mi} + \mu_{j} )}}{2}(u_{j} - u_{mi} ) \cdot \nabla^{2} W(x_{ji} ,h) $$
(30)

where j is the index of the rigid body particles within the SPH particle’s smooth radius.

Experimental results and discussion

We tested our new method on a PC equipped with an Intel Core i7 4700MQ, Nvidia GTX 765 M display card, 16G RAM, and CUDA 7.0. We extracted the isosurface using marching cube algorithm. The simulation scenes were rendered in real time. We depict the fluid by different colors to distinguish the volume fractions among different fluid phases.

Figure 6 records the FPS of our simulation method. The blue polyline represents the FPS of the scene with isosurface, and the orange polyline shows the FPS of that scene without isosurface. Note that the scene is a \( 0.2{\text{m}} \times 0.3{\text{m}} \times 0.2{\text{m}} \) water pool. We changed the number of SPH particles and recorded the FPS. It can be seen from Fig. 6 that, if we did not calculate isosurface, after we added 130 k SPH particles, the frame rates can also reach 28 FPS. After we extracted the isosurface, the simulation can run at 20 FPS with 100 k SPH particles. In previous SPH haptic interactive simulation (Cirio et al. 2011), when SPH particles’ number reaches 100 k, the computation step in simulation has reached 20 FPS. In contrast, our result is 37 FPS, which is a significant improvement compared with Cirio et al. (2011). Figure 7 is similar to Fig. 6, where we can see that the amount of rigid body particles slightly influences the efficiency of simulation if the number of rigid body particles is not so much.

In Fig. 8, we defined the motion trajectory of a ball to make it move from one side of water pool to another corner. We compared the output haptic force with single-phase fluid and two-phase immiscible fluid, the result of which is shown in Fig. 9. We can see from 8(a) that the haptic force from water is low at the beginning; then along with the increase in ball’s velocity, the haptic force becomes higher. When the ball slows down, the haptic force fluctuates with the motion of the fluid, and the haptic force finally decreases to a lower level. In experiment 8(b), we add another kind of fluid, the haptic force changes obviously when the ball is located in the mixed area, and the haptic force decreases with less fluctuation. This is due to that the green fluid’s density and viscosity are lower than those of the blue one. This experiment demonstrates that our haptic force computation scheme can greatly distinguish the differences among different phases of fluid.

Figure 10 shows a comparison of fluid mixing results generated by different state-of-the-art methods. Under artificial waves, we mixed three phases of fluid. Figure 10a is the result of three phases which are immiscible with each other (under \( \sigma_{\text{dif}} = 0 \)), Fig. 10b is the result produced by the method in Ren et al. (2014), and Fig. 10c demonstrates our result (under \( \sigma_{\text{dif}} = 0.15 \)). The parameters of different phases are given in Table 1. We can see from Table 2 that our method is more efficient which can achieve comparable simulation with that in Ren et al. (2014).

Figure 11 shows the haptic interaction experiment with three phases of miscible fluid, where we mix the fluid by a ball. In this experiment, three phases of fluids were distributed in a container. Note that the diffusion coefficient \( \sigma_{\text{dif}} \) is 0.1. At the beginning, different phases were mixing slowly; then, we controlled the spoon to interact with fluid. It can be observed that stirring can greatly promote diffusion effect. Our method can simulate the multi-fluid flow and the haptic interaction with it, which is lacked in previous works.

In Fig. 12, we define a circumference track for a moving ball. In this experiment, the ball continually stirred the fluid in the container. We define \( \sigma_{\text{dif}} \) as 0.15. Figure 13 shows the haptic force in a brief period of the simulation. The haptic force is fluctuating with the changing of neighboring SPH particles’ volume fraction.

Conclusion and future work

Interactive fluid simulation can be wildly used in computer games, virtual reality education, and many other applications. In this paper, our research on SPH multi-fluid haptic interaction can provide users with real haptic feedback force, greatly enhancing their realistic sensing in virtual reality. We employed the unified particle model for rigid body–liquid coupling and accurately rendered the haptic force. We designed FIR filter with Hamming window to compute smooth haptic forces. We simulated SPH multi-fluid with a new mixture model and utilized it for our real-time haptic simulation.

In the future, we will improve our control method for more complex situation and double haptic controller. We will also exploit GPUs for acceleration (Yoganandan et al. 2012). The incorporation of chemical reaction simulation and the introduction of state-of-the-art rendering techniques are also our future work.
